For a monoid $M$ and elements $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{n} \in M$, the product is defined as $\prod_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} := a_{1} \cdot \ldots \cdot a_{n}$. A special bracketing on the right-hand side is not necessary due to the associative nature of the law of composition.

A polynomial with coefficients in a field or ring is defined as a formal sum $f=\sum_{j=0}^{n} a_{j} X^{j}$, where $a_{j}$ are the coefficients. This definition emphasizes that a polynomial is identified with the sequence of its coefficients.
A ring R is called commutative if the multiplication is commutative.
In any ring $R$, the zero ideal $\{0\}$ and the unit ideal $R$ are called trivial ideals. These are the only ideals if $R$ is a field.
The map $\delta$ in a Euclidean domain $R$ that facilitates the Euclidean division process.
Homomorphisms between A-modules, also referred to as A-homomorphisms, are defined just as in the context of vector spaces.
The torsion submodule T of an A-module M consists of all torsion elements of M. If T = 0, M is called torsion-free; if T = M, it is called a torsion module.
The extension field $L$ is called algebraic over $K$ if every element $\alpha \in L$ is algebraic over $K$.

An algebraic subset of \(\bar{K}^{n}\) defined over \(K\) is the set of common zeros in \(\bar{K}^{n}\) of the polynomials belonging to a subset \(E\) of the polynomial ring \(K[X]=K\left[X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right]\). It is denoted as \(V(E)\).
Let $G$ be a group and $S \subset G$ a subset. The centralizer of $S$ in $G$ is given by $Z_{S}=\{x \in G ; x s=s x \text { for all } s \in S\} .$
A cycle involving $r$ elements is called an $r$-cycle and is denoted as $\pi = (x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r})$.
The image of a function \( f: A 	o B \) is the set of all elements in \( B \) that have at least one corresponding element in \( A \) via the function \( f \).
